utterances: Now, a lot of people would hear what you're saying, and they would think that has to lead to Senator McCain?
No, not all.
I don't have a penchant for either one.
Sarah Palin's name comes up a lot and incites a range of reactions.
Trisha May(ph), who's single, lives in a studio apartment with a house plant, and works in software, has found her head turned.
I have Democratic tendencies, but I'm really impressed with Palin right now.
She seems to be calm, and collected, and more objective.
Colonel Yancy, who doesn't like any presidential candidate very much, says that the governor of Alaska...
I think she's the best thing around.
I think she's better than all the rest of them.
I wish she was running for president.
But Ella Segor(ph) from Emporia, Virginia, who runs an office leasing agency, believes that Governor Palin's pregnant daughter demonstrates a flaw in the governor's management skills.
She wasn't paying attention, because a 17-year-old that has that much leniency, she wasn't paying attention.
But Robin Jackson, the delivery service driver, finds that argument offensive to her.
That's just like saying, OK, can I get out here and deliver my truck and still come home and take care of my family?
Of course I can.
Why shouldn't she be able to do the same thing?
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Every morning there's a different music show for children at Jammin' Java in Vienna, Virginia, which is well beyond the beltway that encircles Washington.
Young mothers balance children in their laps as they sip coffee, and their youngsters squirm as a folk singer entertains.
Mary Rust(ph), who says she is usually a Republican, sits on the floor with her 7-month-old son Hayden(ph).
I have always been for McCain.
I'm a little cautious now, but I'm going to wait and see.
You know, I'm going to wait until I know everything on both ends before I make a decision.
A woman named Jennifer(ph) describes herself as a former Republican who doesn't like the choice of Governor Palin.
I just think she's very inexperienced and...
Is she, in your mind, substantially less experienced than Senator Obama?
I don't know how to say this without sounding like an elitist.
I think she's substantially less intelligent.
I trust him more with his life experience to make an intelligent, measured decision.
Jennifer says her own life experience altered her political direction when she had an autistic child.
She blames a Republican governor of Virginia and other politicians for cutting spending on children with special needs.
Fairfax County, which is one of the wealthiest counties in the country, has no autism resource (unintelligible) anymore.
I see the Democrats as the education party, I really do.
And that's been having three kids, especially with a special needs child.
I have to vote for that party.
I hope maybe that having her there, if they win, maybe will change some of the Republican policies towards special needs children, but I don't have great hopes of it.
Late afternoons, three friends, all retired from federal jobs, meet for coffee and conversation.
A man named Rich(ph) also describes himself as a former Republican who will probably vote for Barack Obama.
He says he isn't impressed by the experience of any of the presidential and vice presidential candidates, even Joe Biden who's head of the Foreign Relations Committee.
He's famous for foreign policy.
But economics and other things, I don't know.
Obama does seem to be a junior and perhaps not fully tested in crisis.
Could he stand up to the Iranian mullahs, people like this?
Will he stand up and fight, I wonder?
McCain, you can call him a maverick, but he appoints people who are not qualified.
So, is he idealistic?
Is he even present?
If you're counting, our informal survey probably brought us into contact with a couple more Obama than McCain voters in Northern Virginia.
Statewide polls show a virtual tie.
But even more people said they were undecided or open to changing their minds.
We met a couple of sisters, Pam Orchin(ph) and Pat Kaufman(ph), both non-practicing lawyers, as they made a late afternoon run at an upscale shopping area in Arlington.
We have always been, sort of, on the opposite side of the political spectrum in that way.
And we are at this time.
We are this time.
We are this time, too.
You are at this time, too.
So you both cancel each other out.
We're canceling each other's votes out as we have done for the last 25 years or so.
So, we have a...
I never thought of it that way.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
We don't make a difference.
I mean, we'll certainly be watching the debates, I think, and with great interest, and I'm sure like everyone.
The vice presidential debate is going to be pretty fascinating.
Richard Gray(ph) of Arlington says he's under no illusions that any candidate can deliver on what they say.
I think right now, the way Washington is, I'm not sure that any one of them would get anything through.
I mean, look at what happened with the Congress last time.
The Democrats won it, and we had all these big promises.
They're in there, and all they're doing is fighting.
And now nobody's getting through.
I have to point something out.
We are standing, what, half a mile from Washington?
We just happen to be in another state.
But you - I mean, you talk about Washington like it's...
Far away.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And I live across the river from Washington.
Voters in Northern Virginia, two subway stops from the dreaded place where government dwells, talking just a little over six weeks before Election Day.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Millions of gallons of oil, more than the size of the Exxon Valdez oil tanker spill, are floating in the groundwater under a Brooklyn neighborhood.
The neighborhood is Greenpoint across the East River from Manhattan and where New York hopes to build its Olympic village if it hosts the 2012 Games.
Shia Levitt reports.
It's springtime in this quiet residential area in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
Children are playing ball and riding bikes in the street.
But spend any time in this neighborhood and you'll hear residents complain.
Sometimes, you know, you'll come out, and all of a sudden, `Eww, what's that smell?
you know.
I don't know where the smell comes from, but it's horrible.
If we get a lot of rain, the catch basins and the drains all over, not even just in Greenpoint, you can actually smell gasoline, like as if there was gas poured down the sewer.
Residents Joanne Hanley and Larry Paladino live in two of about 100 homes that sit atop one of the largest urban oil spills in America.
Oil began leaking from storage tanks at a former Mobil Oil refinery more than 50 years ago and leaked for several decades.
Dale Desnoyers is director of environmental remediation at the New York state agency overseeing the cleanup.
The protections we have today weren't in effect in the 1920s, and so right now we're basically dealing with industrial practices that occurred 80 or 90 years ago or longer.
ExxonMobil has acknowledged the problem, and in 1990 signed an agreement with the state to take responsibility for the cleanup.
The company recovers close to 20,000 gallons of oil each month from water treatment facilities and oil recovery wells like this one in Greenpoint.
(Soundbite of recovery well running)
Although the state has held ExxonMobil primarily responsible for the bulk of the spill removal efforts, other oil companies also had storage tanks in the area.
Some of these facilities had leaks, as well, which added to the spill.
Today, ExxonMobil, BP and Chevron are involved in the cleanup.
Desnoyers explains.
Under New York state statute, unless you can show that the spills are totally unrelated and can be addressed separately, each party is jointly and separately libel.
So regardless of whether they contributed 10 percent or 80 percent, they're libel to clean up the entire spill.
UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER #4: Give one more burst.
